verses.text: Jacob settled in the land of Canaan, where his father had lived as a foreigner.
verses.comment: This verse establishes the continuity between Jacob and the patriarchal heritage. Canaan is the land of promise, symbolizing God’s covenant faithfulness.

verses.text: These are the generations of Jacob. Joseph, being seventeen years old, was tending the flock with his brothers. He was a youth with the sons of Bilhah and Zilpah, his father’s wives, and Joseph brought a bad report of them to their father.
verses.comment: Joseph's youth and his reporting set the stage for his future role and conflict. The theme of sibling rivalry begins here, foreshadowing later divisions in Israel’s history.

verses.text: Now Israel loved Joseph more than all his other sons, because he was the son of his old age; and he made him a robe of many colors.
verses.comment: The favoritism of Jacob (Israel) is crucial. The multicolored robe indicated special status, setting Joseph apart as chosen among his brothers, a foreshadowing of God’s selection for leadership.

verses.text: But when his brothers saw that their father loved him more than all of them, they hated him and could not speak peaceably to him.
verses.comment: Sibling jealousy leads to hatred and division. The theme of being chosen brings conflict, as seen throughout salvation history.

verses.text: Joseph had a dream, and when he told it to his brothers, they hated him even more.
verses.comment: Dreams in the Bible often signify divine revelation. Joseph’s dreams foreshadow both his suffering and his eventual exaltation, prefiguring Christ’s own path.

verses.text: He said to them, 'Hear this dream that I have dreamed.'
verses.comment: Joseph’s invitation to listen to his dream underscores that divine messages are meant for the community, not just the individual.

verses.text: 'Behold, we were binding sheaves in the field, and suddenly my sheaf arose and stood upright, and your sheaves gathered around and bowed down to my sheaf.'
verses.comment: The imagery of the sheaves suggests future authority and provision, both physically and spiritually. Joseph’s exaltation prefigures Christ receiving homage from all nations.

verses.text: His brothers said to him, 'Are you indeed going to reign over us? Or are you going to rule us?' So they hated him even more for his dreams and for his words.
verses.comment: Rejection of Joseph’s kingship parallels later rejection of God’s chosen leaders and ultimately Christ himself. This mirrors enduring resistance to divinely appointed authority.

verses.text: Then he dreamed another dream and told it to his brothers. He said, 'Look, I have dreamed another dream, and behold, the sun, the moon, and eleven stars were bowing down to me.'
verses.comment: This dream is more cosmic and universal. The sun, moon, and stars represent his father, mother, and brothers. Joseph’s elevation is part of a larger plan involving the whole family of faith.

verses.text: But when he told it to his father and to his brothers, his father rebuked him and said, 'What is this dream that you have dreamed? Shall I and your mother and your brothers indeed come to bow ourselves to the ground before you?'
verses.comment: Jacob’s rebuke shows initial skepticism toward prophetic revelation, often seen throughout scripture. Yet he listens intently, aware of its possible truth.

verses.text: And his brothers envied him, but his father kept the matter in mind.
verses.comment: Jacob meditates on the dream, much like Mary treasured and pondered things in her heart—showing a spiritual depth crucial for responding to God’s revelation.

verses.text: Now his brothers went to pasture their father’s flock near Shechem.
verses.comment: Shechem has been a place of both promise and trouble for Jacob’s family; it symbolizes places of testing and purification.

verses.text: Israel said to Joseph, 'Are not your brothers pasturing the flock at Shechem? Come, I will send you to them.' And Joseph said, 'Here I am.'
verses.comment: Israel’s sending of Joseph foreshadows many biblical ‘sendings’—including Abraham, Moses, and the prophets, and ultimately Christ. Joseph’s willingness echoes obedience.

verses.text: He said to him, 'Go now, see if it is well with your brothers and with the flock, and bring me word.' So he sent him from the valley of Hebron, and he came to Shechem.
verses.comment: The mission to ‘seek the welfare’ mirrors Christ’s own coming to seek out his brethren, moving from Hebron (fellowship) to Shechem (potential danger).

verses.text: A man found him wandering in the fields, and the man asked him, 'What are you seeking?'
verses.comment: Joseph’s seeking is reminiscent of seeking truth and guidance, often a prelude to divine encounter in biblical narratives.

verses.text: He replied, 'I am looking for my brothers. Tell me, please, where they are pasturing the flock.'
verses.comment: Joseph’s search for his brothers emphasizes unity and fraternal concern—a foundational aspect of God’s people.

verses.text: The man said, 'They have moved on from here; I heard them say, “Let us go to Dothan.”' So Joseph went after his brothers and found them at Dothan.
verses.comment: Dothan would later become a place of prophetic revelation and angelic intervention. Joseph seeks them still, embodying persistence in reconciliation.

verses.text: They saw him from a distance, and before he came near them, they plotted against him to kill him.
verses.comment: The brothers’ plot anticipates betrayal of the innocent, a recurring motif, climaxing in the betrayal of Christ.

verses.text: They said to one another, 'Here comes this dreamer.'
verses.comment: Mocking Joseph’s dreams parallels later scoffing at prophets and, ultimately, Christ himself. God’s chosen often face scorn before vindication.

verses.text: 'Come now, let us kill him and throw him into one of the pits. Then we will say that a wild animal has devoured him, and we will see what becomes of his dreams.'
verses.comment: Plotting murder by his own kin symbolizes human resistance to God’s chosen. The pit prefigures later ‘descents’ and ‘risings’ in salvation history.

verses.text: But when Reuben heard it, he rescued him out of their hands, saying, 'Let us not take his life.'
verses.comment: Reuben’s intervention points to mercy among sin. His act is reminiscent of intercession, mediating between justice and compassion.

verses.text: Reuben said to them, 'Shed no blood. Throw him into this pit here in the wilderness, but do not lay a hand on him'—that he might rescue him out of their hand and restore him to his father.
verses.comment: The pit, an image of death and resurrection, points to future ‘deliverance from the pit’ motifs. Reuben intends restoration, a key theme in reconciliation.

verses.text: So when Joseph came to his brothers, they stripped him of his robe, the robe of many colors that he wore.
verses.comment: Stripping Joseph prefigures Christ’s humiliation, where He was stripped before crucifixion. Symbolically, this removes external dignity to reveal true identity.

verses.text: And they took him and threw him into the pit. The pit was empty; there was no water in it.
verses.comment: The pit, often an image of death or Sheol, provides typology for Christ’s burial and later resurrection—as waterless, it is a lifeless place awaiting divine rescue.

verses.text: Then they sat down to eat. And looking up, they saw a caravan of Ishmaelites coming from Gilead, with their camels bearing gum, balm, and myrrh, on their way to take them down to Egypt.
verses.comment: Eating while Joseph is in the pit contrasts dire betrayal with callous normalcy. The mention of myrrh anticipates gifts brought to Christ and hints at sacrificial elements.

verses.text: Then Judah said to his brothers, 'What profit is it if we kill our brother and conceal his blood?'
verses.comment: Judah’s words bring commercial calculation into family betrayal. His leadership here later foreshadows messianic lineage, emphasizing the mystery of redemption through suffering.

verses.text: 'Come, let us sell him to the Ishmaelites, and let not our hand be upon him, for he is our brother, our own flesh.' And his brothers agreed.
verses.comment: Selling Joseph for silver prefigures the betrayal of Christ for silver coins. The emphasis on ‘brother’ shows the tension between kinship and sin.

verses.text: When Midianite traders passed by, they drew Joseph up and lifted him out of the pit, and sold him to the Ishmaelites for twenty pieces of silver. And they took Joseph to Egypt.
verses.comment: The transaction places Joseph in Egypt, where he will save his people—mirroring Christ’s betrayal and subsequent salvation of humanity by coming into the ‘Egypt’ of sin.

verses.text: When Reuben returned to the pit and saw that Joseph was not there, he tore his clothes.
verses.comment: Tearing garments is a sign of mourning and loss in biblical culture, expressing deep anguish common in situations of betrayal and tragedy.

verses.text: He returned to his brothers and said, 'The boy is gone, and I—where shall I go?'
verses.comment: Reuben’s despair reveals his inability to undo what has happened, emphasizing the gravity and consequences of sin. It sets up the motif of lost hope and future restoration.

verses.text: Then they took Joseph’s robe, slaughtered a goat, and dipped the robe in the blood.
verses.comment: The substitution of animal blood and the robe’s staining mirrors sacrificial imagery and points to the later use of blood for atonement in worship. Also, the narrative ties to Jacob’s deception with a goat’s skin.

verses.text: They sent the robe of many colors, and brought it to their father and said, 'We have found this. Please identify whether it is your son’s robe or not.'
verses.comment: Deception by means of clothing recalls earlier family deceit. Clothing in biblical narrative often represents identity, inheritance, and spiritual calling.

verses.text: He identified it and said, 'It is my son’s robe. A wild animal has devoured him; Joseph is surely torn to pieces.'
verses.comment: Jacob’s anguish highlights paternal love and illustrates loss attributed to ‘wild beasts’—symbolic of destructive forces in spiritual life. The mistaken belief in Joseph’s death prefigures the mystery of Christ’s ‘hiddenness’ before resurrection.

verses.text: Then Jacob tore his garments and put sackcloth on his waist, and mourned for his son many days.
verses.comment: Mourning with sackcloth is a ritual sign of deep sorrow, later associated with penitence and expectation of divine comfort through suffering.

verses.text: All his sons and all his daughters rose up to comfort him, but he refused to be comforted and said, 'No, I will go down to Sheol, mourning for my son.' Thus his father wept for him.
verses.comment: Jacob’s mourning is unconsoled, echoing the spiritual principle that comfort sometimes only comes through hope of resurrection. The mention of ‘Sheol’ deepens the anticipation of deliverance from death.

verses.text: Meanwhile, the Midianites sold Joseph in Egypt to Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh, the captain of the guard.
verses.comment: Joseph’s sale into Egypt marks the beginning of his path to exaltation through suffering. Like Christ, he is made a servant through humility before rising to authority for the salvation of many.
